1. Introduction

In earlier work [Ka-RLSFM], Katz exhibited some very simple one parameter families of exponential sums which gave rigid local systems on the affine line in characteristic p𝑝p whose geometric (and usually, arithmetic) monodromy groups were SL2​(q)subscriptSL2𝑞\mathrm{SL}_{2}(q), and he exhibited other such very simple families giving SU3​(q)subscriptSU3𝑞\mathrm{SU}_{3}(q). [Here q𝑞q is a power of the characteristic p𝑝p, and p𝑝p is odd.] In this paper, we exhibit equally simple families whose geometric monodromy groups are the alternating groups Alt​(2​q)Alt2𝑞\mathrm{Alt}(2q). We also determine their arithmetic monodromy groups. See Theorem 3.1. [Of course from the resolution [Ray] of the Abhyankar Conjecture, any finite simple group whose order is divisible by p𝑝p will occur as the geometric monodromy group of some local system on 𝔸1/𝔽¯psuperscript𝔸1subscript¯𝔽𝑝{\mathbb{A}}^{1}/\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_{p}; the interest here is that it occurs in our particularly simple local systems.]

In the earlier work of Katz, he used a theorem to Kubert to know that the monodromy groups in question were finite, then work of Gross [Gross] to determine which finite groups they were. Here we do not have, at present, any direct way of showing this finiteness. Rather, the situation is more complicated and more interesting. Using some basic information about these local systems (cf. Theorem 6.1), the first and third authors prove a fundamental dichotomy: the geometric monodromy group is either Alt​(2​q)Alt2𝑞\mathrm{Alt}(2q) or it is the special orthogonal group SO​(2​q−1)SO2𝑞1\mathrm{SO}(2q-1). The second author uses an elementary polynomial identity to compute the third moment as being 111 (cf. Theorem 7.1), which rules out the SO​(2​q−1)SO2𝑞1\mathrm{SO}(2q-1) case. This roundabout method establishes the theorem. It would be interesting to find a “direct” proof that these local systems have integer (rather than rational) traces; this integrality is in fact equivalent to their monodromy groups being finite, cf. [Ka-ESDE, 8.14.6]. But even if one had such a direct proof, it would still require serious group theory to show that their geometric monodromy groups are the alternating groups.

It is lisse of rank n𝑛n, pure of weight one, and orthogonally self dual, with its geometric monodromy group

Recall that Gg​e​o​msubscript𝐺𝑔𝑒𝑜𝑚G_{geom} is the Zariski closure in SO​(n,ℚℓ¯)SO𝑛¯subscriptℚℓ\mathrm{SO}(n,\overline{{\mathbb{Q}}_{\ell}}) of the image of the geometric fundamental group π1​(𝔸1/k¯)subscript𝜋1superscript𝔸1¯𝑘\pi_{1}({\mathbb{A}}^{1}/\overline{k}) in the representation which “is” the local system ℱ​(k,n,ψ)ℱ𝑘𝑛𝜓{\mathcal{F}}(k,n,\psi). For ease of later reference, we recall the following fundamental fact.

Lemma 2.1.

For any lisse local system on 𝔸1/k¯superscript𝔸1¯𝑘{\mathbb{A}}^{1}/\overline{k}, the subgroup ΓpsubscriptΓ𝑝\Gamma_{p} of its Gg​e​o​msubscript𝐺𝑔𝑒𝑜𝑚G_{geom} generated by elements of p𝑝p-power order is Zariski dense.

Proof.

Denote by N𝑁N the Zariski closure of ΓpsubscriptΓ𝑝\Gamma_{p}. Then N𝑁N is a normal subgroup of Gg​e​o​msubscript𝐺𝑔𝑒𝑜𝑚G_{geom}. We must show that the quotient M:=Gg​e​o​m/Nassign𝑀subscript𝐺𝑔𝑒𝑜𝑚𝑁M:=G_{geom}/N is trivial. We first note that M/M0𝑀superscript𝑀0M/M^{0} is trivial, as it is a finite, prime to p𝑝p quotient of π1​(𝔸1/k¯)subscript𝜋1superscript𝔸1¯𝑘\pi_{1}({\mathbb{A}}^{1}/\overline{k}). Thus M𝑀M is connected. We next show that Mr​e​d:=M/ℛuassignsuperscript𝑀𝑟𝑒𝑑𝑀subscriptℛ𝑢M^{red}:=M/{\mathcal{R}}_{u}, the quotient of M𝑀M by its unipotent radical, is trivial. For this, it suffices to show that M𝑀M has no nontrivial irreducible representations. But any such representation is a local system on 𝔸1/k¯superscript𝔸1¯𝑘{\mathbb{A}}^{1}/\overline{k} which is tamely ramified at ∞\infty, so is trivial. Thus M𝑀M is unipotent. But H1​(𝔸1/k¯,ℚℓ¯)superscript𝐻1superscript𝔸1¯𝑘¯subscriptℚℓH^{1}({\mathbb{A}}^{1}/\overline{k},\overline{{\mathbb{Q}}_{\ell}}) vanishes, so any unipotent local system on 𝔸1/k¯superscript𝔸1¯𝑘{\mathbb{A}}^{1}/\overline{k} is trivial, and hence M𝑀M is trivial. ∎

Let us denote by A​(k,n,ψ)𝐴𝑘𝑛𝜓A(k,n,\psi) the Gauss sum

A​(k,n,ψ):=−χ2​(n​(−1)d)​∑x∈k×ψ​(x)​χ2​(x).assign𝐴𝑘𝑛𝜓subscript𝜒2𝑛superscript1𝑑subscript𝑥superscript𝑘𝜓𝑥subscript𝜒2𝑥A(k,n,\psi):=-\chi_{2}(n(-1)^{d})\sum_{x\in k^{\times}}\psi(x)\chi_{2}(x).

By the Hasse-Davenport relation, for L/k𝐿𝑘L/k an extension of degree d𝑑d, we have

A​(L,n,ψL/k)=(A​(k,n,ψ))d.𝐴𝐿𝑛subscript𝜓𝐿𝑘superscript𝐴𝑘𝑛𝜓𝑑A(L,n,\psi_{L/k})=(A(k,n,\psi))^{d}.

3. The candidate local systems for Alt​(2​q)Alt2𝑞\mathrm{Alt}(2q)

In this section, we specialize the n𝑛n of the previous section to

n=2​q−1=2​(q−1)+1.𝑛2𝑞12𝑞11n=2q-1=2(q-1)+1.

The target theorem is this.

Theorem 3.1.

Let p𝑝p be an odd prime, q𝑞q a power of p𝑝p, k𝑘k a finite field of characteristic p𝑝p, ℓℓ\ell a prime ≠pabsent𝑝\neq p, and ψ𝜓\psi a nontrivial additive character of k𝑘k. For the ℓℓ\ell-adic local system 𝒢​(k,2​q−1,ψ)𝒢𝑘2𝑞1𝜓{\mathcal{G}}(k,2q-1,\psi) on 𝔸1/ksuperscript𝔸1𝑘{\mathbb{A}}^{1}/k, its geometric and arithmetic monodromy groups are given as follows.

  • (1)

    Gg​e​o​m=Alt​(2​q)subscript𝐺𝑔𝑒𝑜𝑚Alt2𝑞G_{geom}=\mathrm{Alt}(2q) in its unique irreducible representation of dimension 2​q−12𝑞12q-1.

  • (2a)

    If −11-1 is a square in k𝑘k, then Gg​e​o​m=Ga​r​i​t​h=Alt​(2​q)subscript𝐺𝑔𝑒𝑜𝑚subscript𝐺𝑎𝑟𝑖𝑡ℎAlt2𝑞G_{geom}=G_{arith}=\mathrm{Alt}(2q).

  • (2b)

    If −11-1 is not a square in k𝑘k, then Ga​r​i​t​h=Sym​(2​q)subscript𝐺𝑎𝑟𝑖𝑡ℎSym2𝑞G_{arith}=\mathrm{Sym}(2q), the symmetric group, in its irreducible representation labeled by the partition (2,12​q−2)2superscript12𝑞2(2,1^{2q-2}), i.e.
    (the​deleted​permutation​representation​of​Sym​(2​q))⊗sgn.tensor-productthedeletedpermutationrepresentationofSym2𝑞sgn{\rm(the\ deleted\ permutation\ representation\ of\ }\mathrm{Sym}(2q))\otimes\mathrm{sgn}.

Remark 3.2.

The traces of elements of Alt​(n)Alt𝑛\mathrm{Alt}(n) (respectively of Sym​(n)Sym𝑛\mathrm{Sym}(n)) in its deleted permutation representation (respectively in every irreducible representation) are integers. One sees easily (look at the action of G​a​l​(ℚ​(ζp)/ℚ)𝐺𝑎𝑙ℚsubscript𝜁𝑝ℚGal({\mathbb{Q}}(\zeta_{p})/{\mathbb{Q}})) that the local system 𝒢​(k,2​q−1,ψ)𝒢𝑘2𝑞1𝜓{\mathcal{G}}(k,2q-1,\psi) has traces which all lie in ℚℚ{\mathbb{Q}}, but as mentioned in the introduction, we do not know a direct proof that these traces all lie in ℤℤ{\mathbb{Z}}.

4. Basic facts about ℋnsubscriptℋ𝑛{\mathcal{H}}_{n}

In this section, we assume that n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3 is odd and that n​(n−1)𝑛𝑛1n(n-1) is prime to p𝑝p. The geometric local monodromy at 00 is tame, and a topological generator of the tame inertia group I​(0)t​a​m​e𝐼superscript0𝑡𝑎𝑚𝑒I(0)^{tame}, acting on ℋnsubscriptℋ𝑛{\mathcal{H}}_{n}, has as eigenvalues all the roots of unity of order dividing n𝑛n.

The geometric local monodromy at ∞\infty is the direct sum

ℒχ2⊕W;W​has​rank​n−1,and​all​slopes​ 1/(n−1).direct-sumsubscriptℒsubscript𝜒2𝑊𝑊hasrank𝑛1andallslopes1𝑛1{\mathcal{L}}_{\chi_{2}}\oplus W;\ \ W{\rm\ has\ rank\ }n-1,\ {\rm and\ all\ slopes\ }1/(n-1).

Because n𝑛n is odd, the local system ℋnsubscriptℋ𝑛{\mathcal{H}}_{n} is (geometrically) orthogonally self dual, and det(ℋn)subscriptℋ𝑛\det({\mathcal{H}}_{n}) is geometrically trivial (because trivial at 00, lisse on 𝔾msubscript𝔾𝑚{\mathbb{G}}_{m}, and all ∞\infty slopes are ≤1/(n−1)<1absent1𝑛11\leq 1/(n-1)<1). Therefore det(W)𝑊\det(W) is geometrically ℒχ2subscriptℒsubscript𝜒2{\mathcal{L}}_{\chi_{2}}. From [Ka-ESDE, 8.6.4 and 8.7.2], we see that up to multiplicative translation, the geometric isomorphism class is determined entirely by its rank n−1𝑛1n-1 and its determinant ℒχ2subscriptℒsubscript𝜒2{\mathcal{L}}_{\chi_{2}}. Because n−1𝑛1n-1 is even and prime to p𝑝p, it follows that up to multiplicative translation, the geometric isomorphism class of W𝑊W is that of the I​(∞)𝐼I(\infty)-representation of the Kloosterman sheaf

K​ln−1:=K​l​(ψ;all​char′​s​of​order​dividing​n−1).assign𝐾subscript𝑙𝑛1𝐾𝑙𝜓allsuperscriptchar′soforderdividing𝑛1Kl_{n-1}:=Kl(\psi;{\rm all\ char^{\prime}s\ of\ order\ dividing\ }n-1).

By [Ka-GKM, 5.6.1], we have a global Kummer direct image geometric isomorphism

K​ln−1≅[n−1]⋆​ℒψn−1,𝐾subscript𝑙𝑛1subscriptdelimited-[]𝑛1⋆subscriptℒsubscript𝜓𝑛1Kl_{n-1}\cong[n-1]_{\star}{\mathcal{L}}_{\psi_{n-1}},

where we write ψn−1subscript𝜓𝑛1\psi_{n-1} for the additive character x↦ψ​((n−1)​x)maps-to𝑥𝜓𝑛1𝑥x\mapsto\psi((n-1)x). Therefore, up to multiplicative translation, the geometric isomorphism class of W𝑊W is that of [n−1]⋆​ℒψsubscriptdelimited-[]𝑛1⋆subscriptℒ𝜓[n-1]_{\star}{\mathcal{L}}_{\psi}. Pulling back by [n−1]delimited-[]𝑛1[n-1], which does not change the restriction of W𝑊W to the wild inertia group P​(∞)𝑃P(\infty), we get

[n−1]⋆​W≅⊕ζ∈μn−1ℒψ​(ζ​x).superscriptdelimited-[]𝑛1⋆𝑊subscriptdirect-sum𝜁subscript𝜇𝑛1subscriptℒ𝜓𝜁𝑥[n-1]^{\star}W\cong\oplus_{\zeta\in\mu_{n-1}}{\mathcal{L}}_{\psi(\zeta x)}.

Thus we find that the I​(∞)𝐼I(\infty) representation attached to a multiplicative translate of [n−1]⋆​ℱ​(k,n,ψ)superscriptdelimited-[]𝑛1⋆ℱ𝑘𝑛𝜓[n-1]^{\star}{\mathcal{F}}(k,n,\psi) is the direct sum

This description shows that the image of P​(∞)𝑃P(\infty) in the I​(∞)𝐼I(\infty)-representation attached to ℱ​(k,n,ψ)ℱ𝑘𝑛𝜓{\mathcal{F}}(k,n,\psi) is an abelian group killed by p𝑝p.

Lemma 4.1.

Let L/𝔽p𝐿subscript𝔽𝑝L/{\mathbb{F}}_{p} be a finite extension which contains the n−1𝑛1n-1’st roots of unity. Denote by V⊂L𝑉𝐿V\subset L the additive subgroup of L𝐿L spanned by the n−1𝑛1n-1’st roots of unity. Denote by V⋆superscript𝑉⋆V^{\star} the Poincaré dual of V𝑉V:

V⋆:=Hom𝔽p​(V,μp​(ℚℓ¯)).assignsuperscript𝑉⋆subscriptHomsubscript𝔽𝑝𝑉subscript𝜇𝑝¯subscriptℚℓV^{\star}:={\rm Hom}_{{\mathbb{F}}_{p}}(V,\mu_{p}(\overline{{\mathbb{Q}}_{\ell}})).

Then the image of P​(∞)𝑃P(\infty) in the I​(∞)𝐼I(\infty)-representation attached to ℱ​(k,n,ψ)ℱ𝑘𝑛𝜓{\mathcal{F}}(k,n,\psi) is V⋆superscript𝑉⋆V^{\star}, and the representation restricted to V⋆superscript𝑉⋆V^{\star} is the direct sum of

Proof.

Each of the characters ℒψ​(α​xn)subscriptℒ𝜓𝛼superscript𝑥𝑛{\mathcal{L}}_{\psi(\alpha x^{n})} of I​(∞)𝐼I(\infty) has order dividing p𝑝p. Given an n𝑛n-tuple of elements (aα)α∈μn−1​(L)∪{0}subscriptsubscript𝑎𝛼𝛼subscript𝜇𝑛1𝐿0(a_{\alpha})_{\alpha\in\mu_{n-1}(L)\cup\{0\}}, consider the character

Λ:=⊗α∈μn−1​(L)∪{0}(ℒψ​(α​xn))⊗aα=\Lambda:=\otimes_{\alpha\in\mu_{n-1}(L)\cup\{0\}}({\mathcal{L}}_{\psi(\alpha x^{n})})^{\otimes a_{\alpha}}=

The following conditions are equivalent.

  • (1)

    ∑α∈μn−1​(L)∪{0}aα​α=0subscript𝛼subscript𝜇𝑛1𝐿0subscript𝑎𝛼𝛼0\sum_{\alpha\in\mu_{n-1}(L)\cup\{0\}}a_{\alpha}\alpha=0.

  • (2)

    The character ΛΛ\Lambda is trivial on I​(∞)𝐼I(\infty).

  • (3)

    The character ΛΛ\Lambda is trivial on P​(∞)𝑃P(\infty).

Indeed, it is obvious that (1)⟹(2)⟹(3)123(1)\implies(2)\implies(3). If (3) holds, then for A:=∑α∈μn−1​(L)∪{0}aα​αassign𝐴subscript𝛼subscript𝜇𝑛1𝐿0subscript𝑎𝛼𝛼A:=\sum_{\alpha\in\mu_{n-1}(L)\cup\{0\}}a_{\alpha}\alpha, we have that ℒψ​(A​x)subscriptℒ𝜓𝐴𝑥{\mathcal{L}}_{\psi(Ax)} is trivial on P​(∞)𝑃P(\infty), so is a character of I​(∞)/P​(∞)=I​(∞)t​a​m​e𝐼𝑃𝐼superscript𝑡𝑎𝑚𝑒I(\infty)/P(\infty)=I(\infty)^{tame}, a group of order prime to p𝑝p. But ℒψ​(A​x)subscriptℒ𝜓𝐴𝑥{\mathcal{L}}_{\psi(Ax)} has order dividing p𝑝p, so is trivial on I​(∞)𝐼I(\infty), hence A=0𝐴0A=0.

This equivalence shows that the character group of the image of P​(∞)𝑃P(\infty) is indeed the 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝{\mathbb{F}}_{p} span of the α𝛼\alpha’s, i.e., it is V𝑉V. The rest is just Poincaré duality of finite abelian groups. ∎

Theorem 6.1.

We have the following two results.

  • (1)

    Gg​e​o​msubscript𝐺𝑔𝑒𝑜𝑚G_{geom} is normalized by an element of SO​(2​q−1,ℚℓ¯)SO2𝑞1¯subscriptℚℓ\mathrm{SO}(2q-1,\overline{{\mathbb{Q}}_{\ell}}) whose eigenvalues are all the roots of unity of order dividing 2​q−12𝑞12q-1 in ℚℓ¯¯subscriptℚℓ\overline{{\mathbb{Q}}_{\ell}}.

  • (2)

    Gg​e​o​msubscript𝐺𝑔𝑒𝑜𝑚G_{geom} contains a subgroup isomorphic to 𝔽q⊕𝔽qdirect-sumsubscript𝔽𝑞subscript𝔽𝑞{\mathbb{F}}_{q}\oplus{\mathbb{F}}_{q}, acting through the virtual representation

    Regfirst⊕Regsecond−𝟙.direct-sumsubscriptRegfirstsubscriptRegsecond1{\rm Reg}_{\rm first}\oplus{\rm Reg}_{\rm second}-{\mathds{1}}.
Proof.

The local system ℱ​(k,2​q−1,ψ)ℱ𝑘2𝑞1𝜓{\mathcal{F}}(k,2q-1,\psi) is, geometrically, a multiplicative translate of the Kummer pullback [2​q−1]⋆​ℋ2​q−1superscriptdelimited-[]2𝑞1⋆subscriptℋ2𝑞1[2q-1]^{\star}{\mathcal{H}}_{2q-1}. As already noted, local monodromy at 00 for ℋ2​q−1subscriptℋ2𝑞1{\mathcal{H}}_{2q-1} is an element of the asserted type. This proves (1). Statement (2) is just a repeating of what was proved in the previous lemma. ∎

Lemma 7.2.

8. Exact determination of Ga​r​i​t​hsubscript𝐺𝑎𝑟𝑖𝑡ℎG_{arith}

Theorem 8.1.

9. Identifying the group

In this section, we use the information obtained earlier to identify the group. We choose a field embedding ℚℓ¯⊂ℂ¯subscriptℚℓℂ\overline{{\mathbb{Q}}_{\ell}}\subset{\mathbb{C}}, so that we may view G:=Gg​e​o​massign𝐺subscript𝐺𝑔𝑒𝑜𝑚G:=G_{geom} as an algebraic group over ℂℂ{\mathbb{C}}.

So let p𝑝p be an odd prime with q𝑞q a power of p𝑝p. We start by assuming that G𝐺G is an irreducible, Zariski closed subgroup of SO​(2​q−1,ℂ)=SO​(V)SO2𝑞1ℂSO𝑉\mathrm{SO}(2q-1,{\mathbb{C}})=\mathrm{SO}(V) such that G𝐺G contains Q𝑄Q, an elementary abelian subgroup of order q2superscript𝑞2q^{2}. Moreover, we assume that we may write Q=Q1×Q2𝑄subscript𝑄1subscript𝑄2Q=Q_{1}\times Q_{2} so that V=V0⊕V1⊕V2𝑉direct-sumsubscript𝑉0subscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2V=V_{0}\oplus V_{1}\oplus V_{2} where V0subscript𝑉0V_{0} is a trivial Q𝑄Q-module, V0⊕Vidirect-sumsubscript𝑉0subscript𝑉𝑖V_{0}\oplus V_{i} is the regular representation for Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} and Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} acts trivially on the other summand. Moreover, we assume that G𝐺G is a quasi-p𝑝p group (in the sense that the subgroup generated by its p𝑝p-elements is Zariski dense), cf. Lemma 2.1.

Lemma 9.1.

V𝑉V is tensor indecomposable for Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1}. More precisely, V≠X1⊗X2𝑉tensor-productsubscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2V\neq X_{1}\otimes X_{2} where the Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i} are Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1}-modules each of dimension ≥2absent2\geq 2.

Proof.

We argue by contradiction. Suppose V=X1⊗X2𝑉tensor-productsubscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2V=X_{1}\otimes X_{2} with each Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i} of (necessarily odd) dimensional ≥2absent2\geq 2 . Let χXisubscript𝜒subscript𝑋𝑖\chi_{X_{i}} be the character of Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} on Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}. So χX1=a0​𝟙+∑aχ​χsubscript𝜒subscript𝑋1subscript𝑎01subscript𝑎𝜒𝜒\chi_{X_{1}}=a_{0}{\mathds{1}}+\sum a_{\chi}\chi and χX2=b0​𝟙+∑bχ​χsubscript𝜒subscript𝑋2subscript𝑏01subscript𝑏𝜒𝜒\chi_{X_{2}}=b_{0}{\mathds{1}}+\sum b_{\chi}\chi where the χ𝜒\chi are the nontrivial characters of Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1}.

We first reduce to the case when both a0,b0subscript𝑎0subscript𝑏0a_{0},b_{0} are nonzero. The multiplicity of the trivial character of Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} in V𝑉V is q𝑞q, so we have

q=a0​b0+∑χaχ​bχ¯.𝑞subscript𝑎0subscript𝑏0subscript𝜒subscript𝑎𝜒subscript𝑏¯𝜒q=a_{0}b_{0}+\sum_{\chi}a_{\chi}b_{\overline{\chi}}.

So either a0​b0subscript𝑎0subscript𝑏0a_{0}b_{0} is nonzero, and we are done, or for some nontrivial χ𝜒\chi we have aχ​bχ¯subscript𝑎𝜒subscript𝑏¯𝜒a_{\chi}b_{\overline{\chi}} nonzero. In this latter case, replace X1subscript𝑋1X_{1} by X1⊗χ¯tensor-productsubscript𝑋1¯𝜒X_{1}\otimes{\overline{\chi}} and X2subscript𝑋2X_{2} by X2⊗χtensor-productsubscript𝑋2𝜒X_{2}\otimes\chi.

Since each nontrivial character χ𝜒\chi of Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} occur exactly once in V𝑉V, for each such χ𝜒\chi we have

1=a0​bχ+aχ​b0+∑ρ≠χaρ​bχ​ρ¯.1subscript𝑎0subscript𝑏𝜒subscript𝑎𝜒subscript𝑏0subscript𝜌𝜒subscript𝑎𝜌subscript𝑏𝜒¯𝜌1=a_{0}b_{\chi}+a_{\chi}b_{0}+\sum_{\rho\neq\chi}a_{\rho}b_{\chi\overline{\rho}}.

In particular we have the inequalities

a0​bχ≤1,aχ​b0≤1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑎0subscript𝑏𝜒1subscript𝑎𝜒subscript𝑏01a_{0}b_{\chi}\leq 1,\ \ a_{\chi}b_{0}\leq 1.

Because a0,b0subscript𝑎0subscript𝑏0a_{0},b_{0} are both nonzero, we infer that if aχ≠0subscript𝑎𝜒0a_{\chi}\neq 0, then aχ=b0=1subscript𝑎𝜒subscript𝑏01a_{\chi}=b_{0}=1 (respectively that if bχ≠0subscript𝑏𝜒0b_{\chi}\neq 0, then a0=bχ=1subscript𝑎0subscript𝑏𝜒1a_{0}=b_{\chi}=1). It cannot be the case that all aχsubscript𝑎𝜒a_{\chi} vanish, otherwise X1subscript𝑋1X_{1} is the trivial module of dimension >1absent1>1. This is impossible so long as X2subscript𝑋2X_{2} is nontrivial, as each nontrivial character of Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} occurs in V𝑉V exactly once. But if all aχsubscript𝑎𝜒a_{\chi} and all bχsubscript𝑏𝜒b_{\chi} vanish, then V𝑉V is the trivial Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} module, which it is not. Therefore a0=1subscript𝑎01a_{0}=1 and, similarly, b0=1subscript𝑏01b_{0}=1, and all aχ,bχsubscript𝑎𝜒subscript𝑏𝜒a_{\chi},b_{\chi} are either 00 or 111. Now use again that the multiplicity of the trivial character of Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} in V𝑉V is q𝑞q, so we have

q=a0​b0+∑χaχ​bχ¯.𝑞subscript𝑎0subscript𝑏0subscript𝜒subscript𝑎𝜒subscript𝑏¯𝜒q=a_{0}b_{0}+\sum_{\chi}a_{\chi}b_{\overline{\chi}}.

This is possible only if all aχsubscript𝑎𝜒a_{\chi} and all bχsubscript𝑏𝜒b_{\chi} are 111. But then each Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i} has dimension q𝑞q, which is impossible, as the product of their dimensions is 2​q−12𝑞12q-1. ∎

Lemma 9.2.

The following statements hold for G𝐺G.

  1. (1)

    G𝐺G preserves no nontrivial orthogonal decomposition of V𝑉V.

  2. (2)

    V𝑉V is not tensor induced for G𝐺G.

Proof.

We first prove (1). We argue by contradiction. Suppose that V=W1⟂…⟂Wr𝑉subscript𝑊1perpendicular-to…perpendicular-tosubscript𝑊𝑟V=W_{1}\perp\ldots\perp W_{r} with r>1𝑟1r>1. Because G𝐺G acts irreducibly, G𝐺G transitively permutes the Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i}, and all the Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} have the same odd dimension d𝑑d (because 2​q−1=r​d2𝑞1𝑟𝑑2q-1=rd). Since r𝑟r divides 2​q−12𝑞12q-1, gcd⁡(r,p)=1𝑟𝑝1\gcd(r,p)=1, so the p𝑝p-group Q𝑄Q fixes at least one of the Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i}, say W1subscript𝑊1W_{1}. Because r>1𝑟1r>1, there are other orbits of Q𝑄Q on the set of blocks. Any of these has cardinality some power of p𝑝p, so the corresponding direct sum of Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i}’s has odd dimension. As 2​q−12𝑞12q-1 is odd, there must be evenly many other orbits, so at least three orbits in total. In each Q𝑄Q-stable odd-dimensional orthogonal space, Q𝑄Q lies in a maximal torus of the corresponding SOSO\mathrm{SO} group, so has a fixed line. Hence dimVQ≥3dimensionsuperscript𝑉𝑄3\dim V^{Q}\geq 3, contradiction.

We next show that V𝑉V is not tensor induced. We argue by contradiction. If V𝑉V is tensor induced, write V=W⊗…⊗W𝑉tensor-product𝑊…𝑊V=W\otimes\ldots\otimes W (with f≥2𝑓2f\geq 2 tensor factors, dimW<dimVdimension𝑊dimension𝑉\dim W<\dim V). Then Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} must act transitively on the set of tensor factors (otherwise the representation for Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} is tensor decomposable and the previous lemma gives a contradiction).

So by Jordan’s theorem, there exists an element y∈Q1𝑦subscript𝑄1y\in Q_{1} that acts fixed point freely on the set of the f𝑓f tensor factors. All such elements are conjugate in GL​(W)≀Sym​(f)≀GL𝑊Sym𝑓\mathrm{GL}(W)\wr\mathrm{Sym}(f) and we have

χV​(y)=(dimW)f/p.subscript𝜒𝑉𝑦superscriptdimension𝑊𝑓𝑝\chi_{V}(y)=(\dim W)^{f/p}.

[Indeed, after replacing y𝑦y by a GL​(W)≀Sym​(f)≀GL𝑊Sym𝑓\mathrm{GL}(W)\wr\mathrm{Sym}(f)-conjugate, the situation is this. Each orbit of y𝑦y on the set of tensor factors has length p𝑝p, and y𝑦y acts on each corresponding p𝑝p-fold self product of W𝑊W, indexed by 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝{\mathbb{F}}_{p}, by mapping ⊗iwisubscripttensor-product𝑖absentsubscript𝑤𝑖\otimes_{i}w_{i} to ⊗iwi+1subscripttensor-product𝑖absentsubscript𝑤𝑖1\otimes_{i}w_{i+1}. In terms of a basis B:={ej}j=1,…,dimWassign𝐵subscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑗1…dimension𝑊B:=\{e_{j}\}_{j=1,...,\dim W} of W, the only diagonal entries of the matrix of y𝑦y on this W⊗psuperscript𝑊tensor-productabsent𝑝W^{\otimes p} are given by the dimWdimension𝑊\dim W vectors e⊗e​…⊗etensor-producttensor-product𝑒𝑒…𝑒e\otimes e...\otimes e with e∈B𝑒𝐵e\in B.] On the other hand, we have χV​(y)=q−1subscript𝜒𝑉𝑦𝑞1\chi_{V}(y)=q-1 for any nonzero element y𝑦y of Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1}. Thus, if d=dimW𝑑dimension𝑊d=\dim W, we have df/p=q−1superscript𝑑𝑓𝑝𝑞1d^{f/p}=q-1. Thus, dimV=df=(q−1)p>2​q−1dimension𝑉superscript𝑑𝑓superscript𝑞1𝑝2𝑞1\dim V=d^{f}=(q-1)^{p}>2q-1, a contradiction.

∎

Corollary 9.3.

Let L≤SO​(V)𝐿SO𝑉L\leq\mathrm{SO}(V) be any subgroup containing G𝐺G and let 1≠N⊲L1subgroup-of𝑁𝐿1\neq N\lhd L. Then N𝑁N acts irreducibly on V𝑉V.

Proof.

We argue by contradiction. Note that the conclusions of Lemmas 9.1 and 9.2 also hold for L𝐿L.

(i) Because N𝑁N is normal in L𝐿L, V𝑉V is completely reducible for N𝑁N. Let V1,…,Vrsubscript𝑉1…subscript𝑉𝑟V_{1},\ldots,V_{r} be the distinct N𝑁N-isomorphism classes of N𝑁N-irreducible submodules of V𝑉V. Because V𝑉V is L𝐿L-self dual, it is a fortiori N𝑁N-self dual. Therefore the set of Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} is stable by passage to the N𝑁N-dual, Vi↦Vi⋆maps-tosubscript𝑉𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖⋆V_{i}\mapsto V_{i}^{\star}. The group L𝐿L acts transitively on the set of the Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i}. Either every Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} is N𝑁N-self-dual, or none is (the L𝐿L-conjugates of an N𝑁N-self dual representation are N𝑁N-self dual).

When we write V𝑉V as the direct sum of its the N𝑁N-isotypic (“homogeneous” in the terminology of [C-R, 49.5]) components,

V=W1⊕…⊕Wr,𝑉direct-sumsubscript𝑊1…subscript𝑊𝑟V=W_{1}\oplus\ldots\oplus W_{r},

then for some integer e≥1𝑒1e\geq 1 we have N𝑁N-isomorphisms

Wi≅e​Vi:=the​direct​sum​of​e​copies​of​Vi.subscript𝑊𝑖𝑒subscript𝑉𝑖assignthedirectsumof𝑒copiesofsubscript𝑉𝑖W_{i}\cong eV_{i}:=\ {\rm the\ direct\ sum\ of\ }e\ {\rm copies\ of\ }V_{i}.

If r>1𝑟1r>1 and all the Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} are self dual, then this is an orthogonal decompositon (because for i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j, the inner product pairing of (any) Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} with (any) Vjsubscript𝑉𝑗V_{j} is an N𝑁N-homomorphism from Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} to Vj⋆≅Vjsuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑗⋆subscript𝑉𝑗V_{j}^{\star}\cong V_{j}, so vanishes). This contradicts Lemma 9.2.

Suppose r>1𝑟1r>1 and no Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} is self-dual. Then the Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} occur in pairs of duals. Therefore both r𝑟r and dimVdimension𝑉\dim V are even, again a contradiction.

(ii) We have shown that r=1𝑟1r=1 and e>1𝑒1e>1, i.e. V≅e​V1𝑉𝑒subscript𝑉1V\cong eV_{1}. Now we apply Clifford’s theorem, cf. [C-R, Theorem 51.7]. Thus L𝐿L preserves the N𝑁N-isomorphism class of V1subscript𝑉1V_{1}, and so we get an irreducible projective representation L↦PGL​(V1)=PSL​(V1)maps-to𝐿PGLsubscript𝑉1PSLsubscript𝑉1L\mapsto\mathrm{PGL}(V_{1})=\mathrm{PSL}(V_{1}), and V𝑉V as a projective representation of L𝐿L is V1⊗Xtensor-productsubscript𝑉1𝑋V_{1}\otimes X with L𝐿L acting (projectively) irreducibly on X𝑋X through L/N𝐿𝑁L/N, and X𝑋X of dimension e𝑒e. Furthermore, the two factor sets associated to these two projective representations are inverses to each other (because the tensor product V1⊗X=Vtensor-productsubscript𝑉1𝑋𝑉V_{1}\otimes X=V is a linear representation of Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1}). Since e​dimV1=dimV=2​q−1𝑒dimensionsubscript𝑉1dimension𝑉2𝑞1e\dim V_{1}=\dim V=2q-1, both e𝑒e and n=dimV1𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑉1n=\dim V_{1} are coprime to p𝑝p.

We now claim that, restricted to Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1}, each of the tensor factors V1subscript𝑉1V_{1} and X𝑋X lifts to a genuine linear representation. Indeed, using the fact that PGL​(n,ℂ)=PSL​(n,ℂ)PGL𝑛ℂPSL𝑛ℂ\mathrm{PGL}(n,{\mathbb{C}})=\mathrm{PSL}(n,{\mathbb{C}}) and the short exact sequence

1→μn→SL​(n,ℂ)→PSL​(n,ℂ)→1,→1subscript𝜇𝑛→SL𝑛ℂ→PSL𝑛ℂ→11\rightarrow\mu_{n}\rightarrow\mathrm{SL}(n,{\mathbb{C}})\rightarrow\mathrm{PSL}(n,{\mathbb{C}})\rightarrow 1,

the obstruction for (V1)|Q1evaluated-atsubscript𝑉1subscript𝑄1(V_{1})|_{Q_{1}}, which is given by the first factor set restricted to Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1}, lies in the cohomology group H2​(Q1,μn)superscript𝐻2subscript𝑄1subscript𝜇𝑛H^{2}(Q_{1},\mu_{n}). As p∤nnot-divides𝑝𝑛p\nmid n while Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} is a p𝑝p-group, this cohomology group vanishes; and so the first factor set restricted to Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} is trivial, whence so is the second. Thus the Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1}-module V𝑉V is tensor decomposable, contradicting Lemma 9.1. ∎

We next show that G𝐺G is finite. It is convenient to use one more fact about G𝐺G. There is a subgroup A𝐴A (namely the group Gg​e​o​msubscript𝐺𝑔𝑒𝑜𝑚G_{geom} for the hypergeometric sheaf ℋ2​q−1subscriptℋ2𝑞1{\mathcal{H}}_{2q-1}) of SO​(V)SO𝑉\mathrm{SO}(V) such that G𝐺G is normal in A𝐴A, A/G𝐴𝐺A/G is cyclic of order dividing 2​q−12𝑞12q-1 and A𝐴A contains an element x𝑥x of order 2​q−12𝑞12q-1 with distinct eigenvalues on V𝑉V.

We also use the fact that G𝐺G has a nontrivial fixed space on V⊗V⊗Vtensor-product𝑉𝑉𝑉V\otimes V\otimes V (Theorem 7.1).

Theorem 9.4.

G𝐺G is finite.

Proof.

Suppose not. Let N𝑁N be any nontrivial normal (closed) subgroup of G𝐺G. By Corollary 9.3, N𝑁N is irreducible on V𝑉V.

(i) Let G0superscript𝐺0G^{0} be the identity component of G𝐺G. We now show that G0superscript𝐺0G^{0} is a simple algebraic group. Taking N=G0𝑁superscript𝐺0N=G^{0}, we have that G0superscript𝐺0G^{0} acts irreducibly and hence is semisimple (as it lies in SO​(V)SO𝑉\mathrm{SO}(V)). Moreover, the center of G0superscript𝐺0G^{0} is trivial (because it consists of scalars in SO​(V)SO𝑉\mathrm{SO}(V)). Therefore if G0superscript𝐺0G^{0} is not simple, it is the product of adjoint groups Ljsubscript𝐿𝑗L_{j}, 1≤j≤t1𝑗𝑡1\leq j\leq t (namely the adjoint forms of the factors of its universal cover), and V𝑉V is the (outer) tensor product V=⊗j=1tVjV=\otimes^{t}_{j=1}V_{j} of nontrivial irreducible Ljsubscript𝐿𝑗L_{j}-modules Vjsubscript𝑉𝑗V_{j}. By [GT, Corollary 2.7], G𝐺G permutes these tensor factors Vjsubscript𝑉𝑗V_{j}. This action is transitive, otherwise we contradict Lemma 9.1. But this implies that V𝑉V is tensor induced for G𝐺G, contradicting Lemma 9.2. Thus G0superscript𝐺0G^{0} is a simple algebraic group.

(ii) Because the subgroup of G𝐺G generated by its p𝑝p-elements is Zariski dense, the finite group G/G0𝐺superscript𝐺0G/G^{0} is generated by its p𝑝p-elements. As p𝑝p is odd, it follows that either G=G0𝐺superscript𝐺0G=G^{0} is a simple algebraic group or p=3𝑝3p=3 and G0=D4​(ℂ)superscript𝐺0subscript𝐷4ℂG^{0}=D_{4}({\mathbb{C}}). [In all other cases, the outer automorphism group, i.e., the automorphism group of the Dynkin diagram of G0superscript𝐺0G^{0}, has order at most 222.] Since A/G𝐴𝐺A/G has odd order, it follows that A≤G𝐴𝐺A\leq G as well unless G0=D4​(ℂ)superscript𝐺0subscript𝐷4ℂG^{0}=D_{4}({\mathbb{C}}) and 333 divides 2​q−12𝑞12q-1.

Suppose first that A𝐴A is connected and so a simple algebraic group. Then it contains a semisimple element x𝑥x acting with distinct eigenvalues. This implies that a maximal torus has all weight spaces of dimension at most 111. Moreover, the module is in the root lattice (since it is odd dimensional and orthogonal). By a result of Howe [Ho] (see also [Pa, Table]), it follows if G≠SO​(V)𝐺SO𝑉G\neq\mathrm{SO}(V), then either G=G2​(ℂ)𝐺subscript𝐺2ℂG=G_{2}({\mathbb{C}}) with dimV=7dimension𝑉7\dim V=7 or G=PGL2​(ℂ)𝐺subscriptPGL2ℂG=\mathrm{PGL}_{2}({\mathbb{C}}). If dimV=7dimension𝑉7\dim V=7, then q=4𝑞4q=4, a contradiction. If G=PGL2​(ℂ)𝐺subscriptPGL2ℂG=\mathrm{PGL}_{2}({\mathbb{C}}), then any finite abelian subgroup of odd order is cyclic and so Q𝑄Q does not embed in G𝐺G.

So G=SO​(V)𝐺SO𝑉G=\mathrm{SO}(V). However, SO​(V)SO𝑉\mathrm{SO}(V) has no nonzero fixed points on V⊗V⊗Vtensor-product𝑉𝑉𝑉V\otimes V\otimes V and this contradicts Theorem 7.1.

Thus, it follows that A𝐴A is disconnected. So the connected component is D4​(ℂ)subscript𝐷4ℂD_{4}({\mathbb{C}}) and this acts irreducibly on V𝑉V. If D4​(ℂ)subscript𝐷4ℂD_{4}({\mathbb{C}}) contains the element of order 2​q−12𝑞12q-1, then a maximal torus has all weight space of dimension 111 and again using [Ho], we obtain a contradiction. If not, then 333 divides 2​q−12𝑞12q-1, whence p≥5𝑝5p\geq 5 and Q≤D4​(ℂ)𝑄subscript𝐷4ℂQ\leq D_{4}({\mathbb{C}}). Any elementary abelian p𝑝p-subgroup of D4​(ℂ)subscript𝐷4ℂD_{4}({\mathbb{C}}) is contained in a torus and so again we see that the connected component has all weight spaces of dimension at most 111 and we obtain the final contradiction using [Ho]. ∎

Let F∗​(X)superscript𝐹𝑋F^{*}(X) denote the generalized Fitting subgroup of a finite group X𝑋X (so X𝑋X is almost simple precisely when F∗​(X)superscript𝐹𝑋F^{*}(X) is a non-abelian simple group).

Corollary 9.5.

A𝐴A and G𝐺G are almost simple and F∗​(A)=F∗​(G)superscript𝐹𝐴superscript𝐹𝐺F^{*}(A)=F^{*}(G) acts irreducibly on V𝑉V.

Proof.

Let N𝑁N be a minimal normal subgroup of G𝐺G. By Corollary 9.3, N𝑁N acts irreducibly, and so by Schur’s lemma CA​(N)=Z​(N)=1subscript𝐶𝐴𝑁𝑍𝑁1C_{A}(N)=Z(N)=1 as A<SO​(V)𝐴SO𝑉A<\mathrm{SO}(V) with dimVdimension𝑉\dim V odd. So N𝑁N is a direct product of non-abelian simple groups. Arguing as in p. (i) of the proof of Theorem 9.4, we see that N𝑁N is non-abelian simple (otherwise the module V𝑉V would be tensor induced). As CG​(N)=1subscript𝐶𝐺𝑁1C_{G}(N)=1, we see that N⊲G≤Aut​(N)subgroup-of𝑁𝐺Aut𝑁N\lhd G\leq\mathrm{Aut}(N), and so G𝐺G is almost simple and F∗​(G)=Nsuperscript𝐹𝐺𝑁F^{*}(G)=N.

Now, as G⊲Asubgroup-of𝐺𝐴G\lhd A, A𝐴A normalizes N𝑁N. Again since CA​(N)=1subscript𝐶𝐴𝑁1C_{A}(N)=1 we have that N⊲A≤Aut​(N)subgroup-of𝑁𝐴Aut𝑁N\lhd A\leq\mathrm{Aut}(N), and so A𝐴A is almost simple and F∗​(A)=Nsuperscript𝐹𝐴𝑁F^{*}(A)=N. ∎

We next observe that:

Lemma 9.6.

F∗​(G)superscript𝐹𝐺F^{*}(G) is not a sporadic simple group.

Proof.

Notice that both G𝐺G and A𝐴A are generated by elements of odd order (p𝑝p-elements for G𝐺G, these and elements of order 2​q−12𝑞12q-1 for A𝐴A). On the other hand, we have S≤G≤A≤Aut​(S)𝑆𝐺𝐴Aut𝑆S\leq G\leq A\leq\mathrm{Aut}(S) for S=F∗​(G)𝑆superscript𝐹𝐺S=F^{*}(G). One knows [Atlas] that if S𝑆S is sporadic, then |Out​(S)|≤2Out𝑆2|\mathrm{Out}(S)|\leq 2. Therefore, if S𝑆S is a sporadic simple group, then G=A=S𝐺𝐴𝑆G=A=S. The result now folllows easily from information in [Atlas]. Namely, we observe that if q𝑞q is an odd prime power with q2superscript𝑞2q^{2} dividing |G|𝐺|G|, then G𝐺G has no irreducible representation of dimension 2​q−12𝑞12q-1. ∎

We next consider the case F∗​(G)=Alt​(n)superscript𝐹𝐺Alt𝑛F^{*}(G)=\mathrm{Alt}(n). First note Alt​(5)Alt5\mathrm{Alt}(5) contains no noncyclic elementary abelian groups of odd order and so is ruled out. Since 2​q−12𝑞12q-1 is odd, we see that if G=Alt​(n)𝐺Alt𝑛G=\mathrm{Alt}(n), then A=G=Alt​(n)𝐴𝐺Alt𝑛A=G=\mathrm{Alt}(n) (as the outer automorphism group of Alt​(n)Alt𝑛\mathrm{Alt}(n) is a 222-group).

Theorem 9.7.

Let Γ=Alt​(n)ΓAlt𝑛\Gamma=\mathrm{Alt}(n) with n≥6𝑛6n\geq 6. Suppose that x∈Γ𝑥Γx\in\Gamma has odd order and V𝑉V is an irreducible ℂ​[Γ]ℂdelimited-[]Γ{\mathbb{C}}[\Gamma]-module such that x𝑥x acts as a semisimple regular element on V𝑉V. Then one the following holds:

  • (1)

    V𝑉V is the deleted permutation module of dimension n−1𝑛1n-1 (i.e. the nontrivial irreducible constituent of ℂAlt​(n−1)Alt​(n)superscriptsubscriptℂAlt𝑛1Alt𝑛{\mathbb{C}}_{\mathrm{Alt}({n-1})}^{\mathrm{Alt}(n)}), and x𝑥x is either an n𝑛n-cycle (for n𝑛n odd) or a product of two disjoint cycles of coprime lengths (for n𝑛n even); or

  • (2)

    n=8𝑛8n=8, x𝑥x has order 151515 and dimV=14dimension𝑉14\dim V=14.

Proof.

First note that if V𝑉V is the deleted permutation module of dimension n−1𝑛1n-1, an element with 333 or more disjoint cycles has at least a two dimensional fixed space on V𝑉V. Similarly, if x𝑥x has two disjoint cycles of lengths which are not coprime, then x𝑥x has a two dimensional eigenspace on V𝑉V.

Next we observe that if x𝑥x is semisimple regular on V𝑉V, then the order of x𝑥x is at least dimVdimension𝑉\dim V. This proves the result for 6≤n≤146𝑛146\leq n\leq 14 by inspection of the odd order elements and dimensions of the irreducible modules, aside from the case n=8𝑛8n=8 and dimV=14dimension𝑉14\dim V=14 (note that Alt​(8)Alt8\mathrm{Alt}(8) contains an element of order 151515). Recall that Alt​(8)≅GL4​(2)Alt8subscriptGL42\mathrm{Alt}(8)\cong\mathrm{GL}_{4}(2) and it acts 222-transitively on the nonzero vectors. The only irreducible module of dimension 141414 is the irreducible summand of the permutation module of dimension 151515. In this case x𝑥x has a single orbit in the permutation representation and so x𝑥x is semisimple regular on V𝑉V.

Now assume that n≥15𝑛15n\geq 15.

Suppose first that x𝑥x has at most three nontrivial cycles. Then the order of x𝑥x is less than (n/3)3=n3/27superscript𝑛33superscript𝑛327(n/3)^{3}=n^{3}/27 and so dimV<n3/27dimension𝑉superscript𝑛327\dim V<n^{3}/27. Let W𝑊W be a complex irreducible Sym​(n)Sym𝑛\mathrm{Sym}(n)-module whose restriction to Alt​(n)Alt𝑛\mathrm{Alt}(n) contains V|Alt​(n)evaluated-at𝑉Alt𝑛V|_{\mathrm{Alt}(n)}. Since 2≤dimW<2​n3/272dimension𝑊2superscript𝑛3272\leq\dim W<2n^{3}/27, it follows by [Ra, Result 3] that W≅Sλ𝑊superscript𝑆𝜆W\cong S^{\lambda} or Sλ⊗sgntensor-productsuperscript𝑆𝜆sgnS^{\lambda}\otimes{\mathrm{sgn}}, where Sλsuperscript𝑆𝜆S^{\lambda} is the Specht module labeled by the partition λ𝜆\lambda of n𝑛n, with λ=(n−1,1)𝜆𝑛11\lambda=(n-1,1), (n−2,2)𝑛22(n-2,2), or (n−2,1,1)𝑛211(n-2,1,1). Restricting back to Alt​(n)Alt𝑛\mathrm{Alt}(n), we see that V|Alt​(n)=Sλ|Alt​(n)evaluated-at𝑉Alt𝑛evaluated-atsuperscript𝑆𝜆Alt𝑛V|_{\mathrm{Alt}(n)}=S^{\lambda}|_{\mathrm{Alt}(n)}.

Note that

dimS(n−2,1,1)=(n−1)​(n−2)/2,dimS(n−2,2)=n​(n−3)/2.formulae-sequencedimensionsuperscript𝑆𝑛211𝑛1𝑛22dimensionsuperscript𝑆𝑛22𝑛𝑛32\dim S^{(n-2,1,1)}=(n-1)(n-2)/2,\ \ \dim S^{(n-2,2)}=n(n-3)/2.

It is straightforward to see that the dimension of the fixed space of x𝑥x on either of these modules is at least two dimensional, a contradiction. Hence λ=(n−1,1)𝜆𝑛11\lambda=(n-1,1) and V|Alt​(n)evaluated-at𝑉Alt𝑛V|_{\mathrm{Alt}(n)} is the deleted permutation module of dimension n−1𝑛1n-1.

We now induct on n𝑛n. The base case n≤14𝑛14n\leq 14 has already done. We may assume that x𝑥x has at least four nontrivial cycles (each of odd length, as x𝑥x has odd order). View x∈J:=Alt​(a)×Alt​(b)𝑥𝐽assignAlt𝑎Alt𝑏x\in J:=\mathrm{Alt}(a)\times\mathrm{Alt}(b). where the projection into Alt​(b)Alt𝑏\mathrm{Alt}(b) is a b𝑏b-cycle and so the projection into Alt​(a)Alt𝑎\mathrm{Alt}(a) is a product of at least three disjoint cycles. Thus, a≥9𝑎9a\geq 9. Let W𝑊W be an irreducible J𝐽J-submodule of V𝑉V with Alt​(a)Alt𝑎\mathrm{Alt}(a) acting nontrivially. So W=W1⊗W2𝑊tensor-productsubscript𝑊1subscript𝑊2W=W_{1}\otimes W_{2} with W1subscript𝑊1W_{1} an irreducible Alt​(a)Alt𝑎\mathrm{Alt}(a)-module. Then x𝑥x must be multiplicity free on each Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} and by induction x𝑥x can have at most two cycles in Alt​(a)Alt𝑎\mathrm{Alt}(a), a contradiction. ∎

Note that the previous result does fail for n=5𝑛5n=5. Alt​(5)Alt5\mathrm{Alt}(5) has a 555-dimensional representation in which an element of order 555 has all eigenvalues occurring once. Thus if G=Alt​(n)𝐺Alt𝑛G=\mathrm{Alt}(n), we see that n=2​q𝑛2𝑞n=2q and V𝑉V is the deleted permutation module.

Corollary 9.8.

If G=Gg​e​o​m𝐺subscript𝐺𝑔𝑒𝑜𝑚G=G_{geom} is an alternating group Alt​(n)Alt𝑛\mathrm{Alt}(n) for some n𝑛n, then n=2​q𝑛2𝑞n=2q.


Finally, we consider the case where G𝐺G is an almost simple finite group of Lie type, defined over 𝔽ssubscript𝔽𝑠{\mathbb{F}}_{s}, where s=s0f𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑠0𝑓s=s_{0}^{f} is a power of a prime s0subscript𝑠0s_{0}. Let us denote

We will freely use information on character tables of simple groups available in [Atlas, GAP], as well as degrees of complex irreducible characters of various quasisimple groups of Lie type available in [Lu]. Finally, we will also use bounds on the smallest degree d​(S)𝑑𝑆d(S) of nontrivial complex irreducible representations of S𝑆S as listed in [T, Table 1].

Theorem 9.10.

again a contradiction. Next, if S=G2​(3)𝑆subscript𝐺23S=G_{2}(3), then 2​q−1≤162𝑞1162q-1\leq 16 cannot be a degree of an irreducible character of S𝑆S. Finally, if S=G22​(s)𝑆superscriptsubscript𝐺22𝑠S={}^{2}\!G_{2}(s), then

s2−s+1=d​(S)≤2​q−1≤(s+1)​f≤(s+1)​s/3,superscript𝑠2𝑠1𝑑𝑆2𝑞1𝑠1𝑓𝑠1𝑠3s^{2}-s+1=d(S)\leq 2q-1\leq(s+1)f\leq(s+1)s/3,

again a contradiction since s≥27𝑠27s\geq 27.

∎

Our proof is now concluded by applying Theorem 9.7. ∎
